modules.comments: Some specialized functions can be found here.

declarations.comments:
Sort by multiple comparison functions.
Similar to SQL where you can specificy multiple columns with ASC and DESC.
When a comparison function gives EQ the next one is tried.

Other functions don't have a Multiple variant such as sortOnByMultiple. Because the implementation of this function is so simple it serves as example function.
`sortByMultiple comps xs = sortBy (fold comps) xs`

```purescript
let datas = [{a: 2, b: 4}, {a: 3, b: 4}, {a: 2, b: 5}, {a: 1, b: 5}]
    a {a: a1} {a: a2} = compare a1 a2
    b {b: b1} {b: b2} = compare b1 b2 -- use flip for DESC, or alternatively: compare b2 b1
in  sortByMultiple [a, flip b] datas = [{a: 1, b: 5}, {a: 2, b: 5}, {a: 2, b: 4}, {a: 3, b: 4}]
```
declarations.title: sortByMultiple

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection.

```purescript
sortOn (\x -> if x == "dog" then 2 else 1) ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOn

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection.
This version of sortOn uses the decorate-sort-undecorate paradigm or Schwartzian transform. Which means the projection for each entry will only be computed once at the cost of creating more data structures. You will have to benchmark your specific situation to find out whether `sortOn` or `sortOn'` is faster.

```purescript
sortOn' (\x -> if x == "dog" then 2 else 1) ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOn'

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection and sort by a given comparison function.

```purescript
sortOnBy (\x -> if x == "dog" then 2 else 1) compare ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOnBy

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection and sort by a given comparison function.
This version of sortOnBy uses the decorate-sort-undecorate paradigm or Schwartzian transform. Which means the projection for each entry will only be computed once at the cost of creating more data structures. You will have to benchmark your specific situation to find out whether `sortOnBy` or `sortOnBy'` is faster.

```purescript
sortOnBy' (\x -> if x == "dog" then 2 else 1) compare ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOnBy'

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection and sort by a given comparison function.
When the projection returns Nothing those items will be placed last. Useful if your Array contains items with missing data to sort on

```purescript
sortOnByMaybe (\x -> if x == "dog" then Just 2 else Just 1) compare ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOnByMaybe

declarations.comments:
Sort a list by a projection and sort by a given comparison function.
When the projection returns Nothing those items will be placed last. Useful if your Array contains items with missing data to sort on
This version of sortOnByMaybe uses the decorate-sort-undecorate paradigm or Schwartzian transform. Which means the projection for each entry will only be computed once at the cost of creating more data structures. You will have to benchmark your specific situation to find out whether `sortOnByMaybe` or `sortOnByMaybe'` is faster.

```purescript
sortOnByMaybe' (\x -> if x == "dog" then Just 2 else Just 1) compare ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] = ["apple", "kiwi", "dog"]
```
declarations.title: sortOnByMaybe'

declarations.comments:
Partitions an array of Either into two arrays. All the Left elements are put, in order, into the left field of the output record. Similarly the Right elements are put into the right field of the output record.
Note that this function is an alias for `partitionMap` from `Data.Filterable`.
The function is included in this library for people who prefer this name for the function as they might be used to it from [haskell](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/base-4.19.0.0/docs/Data-Either.html#v:partitionEithers)

```purescript
partitionEithers (\a -> if a > 2 then Left a else Right a) [1,2,3,4] == {left: [1,2], right: [3,4]}
```
declarations.title: partitionEithers

declarations.comments:
Get all combinations when drawing n elements from an array.
n must be greater than 0 and not greater than the length of the array otherwise this function returns `Nothing`

```purescript
let products = [{product: "bread", amount: 1}, {product: "cheese", amount: 2}, {product: "bread", amount: 3}]
combinations 2 [1,2,3] -> Just [[1,2], [2,3], [1,3]]
```
declarations.title: combinations

declarations.comments:
Takes an element from each array in turn to produce a new array.

```purescript
interleave [[1,2], [3,4]] = [1,3,2,4]
concat     [[1,2], [3,4]] = [1,2,3,4]
```
declarations.title: interleave

modules.name: Data.Array.Extra

declarations.comments:
Checks if two arrays have exactly the same elements.
The order of elements does not matter.

```purescript
sameElements ["A", "B", "B"] ["B", "A", "B"] == true
sameElements ["A", "B", "B"] ["A", "B"] == false
```
declarations.title: sameElements

declarations.comments:
Try to make a projection from an array. Return an array with the projection and the original array with the elements removed.

```purescript
partitionMaybe (\x -> if x == "dog" then Just "cat" else Nothing) ["apple", "dog", "kiwi"] == { no: ["apple", "kiwi"], yes: ["cat"] }
```
declarations.title: partitionMaybe

declarations.comments:
Count the amount of times a value occurs in an array.
Requires an Ord instance for Map. This function should be faster than `occurrences`

```purescript
occurrencesMap ["A", "B", "B"] == Map.fromList [Tuple "A" 1, Tuple "B" 2]
```
declarations.title: occurrencesMap

declarations.comments:
Count the amount of times a value occurs in an array.
Mostly useful for when you can not define an Ord instance

```purescript
occurrences ["A", "B", "B"] == [Tuple "A" 1, Tuple "B" 2]
```
declarations.title: occurrences

declarations.comments:
Map an array conditionally, only return the array when at least one element was mapped.
Elements that are not mapped will keep the old value.

```purescript
mapMaybeAny (\_ -> Nothing) [1,2,3] == Nothing
mapMaybeAny (\x -> if x == 2 then Just 99 else Nothing) [1,2,3] == Just [1,99,3]
```
declarations.title: mapMaybeAny

declarations.comments:
Map with a function that yields `Either`. Only succeeding when all elements where mapped to `Right`.
Hint: if you don't care about collecting all the Left's (error conditions) and you are looking for a function like
`forall a b c. (a -> Either c b) -> Array a -> Either c (Array b)` then use `traverse` from `Data.Traversable`.
declarations.title: mapEither

declarations.comments:
Similar to `groupMaybe`, adds the ability to map over the thing being grouped.
Useful for removing data that was only there to do the grouping.

```purescript
groupMaybeMap (\x -> Just $ if even x then "even" else "odd") (*3) [1,2,3] == [(Tuple "odd" [3,9]), (Tuple "even" [6])]
groupMaybeMap f identity xs = groupMaybe f xs
```
declarations.title: groupMaybeMap

declarations.comments:
Similar to `group`, adds the ability to group by a projection.
The projection is returned as the first argument of the Tuple.

```purescript
groupMaybe (\x -> Just $ if even x then "even" else "odd") [1,2,3] == [(Tuple "odd" [1,3]), (Tuple "even" [2])]
```
declarations.title: groupMaybe

declarations.comments:
Combines multiple predicates into one. Only one has to match.

```purescript
let preds = anyPredicate [(_ > 5), (_ > 10)]
all preds [5,10] == true
all preds [1,5,10] == false
any preds [1,5] == true
any preds [1] == false
```
declarations.title: anyPredicate

declarations.comments:
Combines multiple predicates into one. All have to match.

```purescript
let preds = allPredicate [(_ > 5), (_ > 10)]
all preds [10,20] == true
all preds [5,10,20] == false
any preds [1,5,10] == true
any preds [1,5] == false
```
declarations.title: allPredicate

declarations.comments:
Map an array conditionally, only return the array when at least one element was mapped.
Elements that are not mapped will keep the old value.

Hint: mapAll can be found in Data.Semigroup.Traversable.Extra

```purescript
mapAny (\_ -> Nothing) (Data.Array.NonEmpty.cons' 1 [2, 3]) == Nothing
mapAny (\x -> if x == 2 then Just 99 else Nothing) (Data.Array.NonEmpty.cons' 1 [2, 3]) == Data.Array.NonEmpty.fromArray [1,99,3]
```
Not that in the second example the `Just` is implicit.
declarations.title: mapAny

declarations.comments: Like map but extracts the replaced values into an array. Allows modification of the replaced values as well.
declarations.title: mapModify

declarations.comments:
Same as mapMaybeWrite but allows modification of replaced values before returning them.
Useful when the old and new values need to be linked to each other.
declarations.title: mapMaybeWriteModify

declarations.comments: Conditionally map the function over the the functor. Returns a Tuple with the new functor and the replaced values.
declarations.title: mapMaybeWrite

declarations.comments:
Map an array conditionally, only return the array when all elements were mapped.
Note that this function is an alias for `traverse`. This is specific behavior for the implementation of `<*>` for `Applicative Maybe`.

Hint: mapAny can be found in Data.Foldable.Extra

```purescript
mapAll (\x -> if x == 2 then Just 99 else Nothing) [1,2,3] == Nothing
mapAll (\x -> Just (x * 2)) [1,2,3] == Just [2,4,6]
```
declarations.title: mapAll

declarations.comments:
Find the all the indices for which a predicate holds.

```purescript
findIndices (contains $ Pattern "b") ["a", "bb", "b", "d"] = [1, 2]
findIndices (contains $ Pattern "x") ["a", "bb", "b", "d"] = []
```
declarations.title: findIndices

declarations.comments:
Find all elements matching a predicate and replace them with another element.

```purescript
updateAllWith odd 4 [1,2,3] == Just [4,2,4]
```
declarations.title: updateAllWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array with the element replaced by an array.

```purescript
updateAllArrayWith odd [21,22] [1,2,3,4,5] == Just [21,22,2,21,22,4,21,22]
```
declarations.title: updateAllArrayWith

declarations.comments:
Find all elements matching a predicate and modify each element found.

```purescript
modifyAllWith odd (* 3) [1,2,3] == Just [3,2,9]
```
declarations.title: modifyAllWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array without that element when it was found.

```purescript
deleteWith (_ == 2) [2,1,3,2] == Just [1,3]
```
declarations.title: deleteWith

declarations.comments:
Like `difference` in `Data.Array` but removes all of the elements from the first array which have a match in the second array.

```purescript
difference [2, 1, 2] [2, 3] == [1,2] -- Data.Array
difference [2, 1, 2] [2, 3] == [1]   -- Data.Array.Extra.All
```
declarations.title: difference

modules.comments: Functions that find the first matching element based on a predicate and then do something with the array.

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return it together with the array without the element.

```purescript
pick (_ == 2) [1,2,3] == Just {yes: 2, no: [1,3]}
```
declarations.title: pick

declarations.comments:
Find an element and return an array without that element when it was found.

```purescript
delete [2,1,3,2] 2 == Just [1,3,2]
```
declarations.title: delete

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array without that element when it was found.

```purescript
deleteWith (_ == 2) [2,1,3,2] == Just [1,3,2]
```
declarations.title: deleteWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate, replace it with another element and return the updated array when it was found

```purescript
updateWith (_ == 2) 4 [1,2,3] == Just [1,4,3]
```
declarations.title: updateWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array with the element replaced by an array.

```purescript
updateFirstArrayWith (_ == 2) [21,22] [1,2,3,4,5] == Just [1,2,21,22,3,4,5]
```
declarations.title: updateFirstArrayWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate, apply a function to it and return the updated array when it was found

```purescript
modifyWith (_ == 2) (* 3) [1,2,3] == Just [1,6,3]
```
declarations.title: modifyWith

declarations.comments:
Modify an element when it was found by the predicate or append a new element to the end of the array.

```purescript
modifyOrSnoc (_ == 2) (* 3) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,6,3]
modifyOrSnoc (_ == 4) (* 3) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,2,3,11]
```
declarations.title: modifyOrSnoc

declarations.comments:
Modify an element when it was found by the predicate or push a new element to the front of the array.

```purescript
modifyOrCons (_ == 2) (* 3) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [1,6,3]
modifyOrCons (_ == 4) (* 3) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [11,1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: modifyOrCons

declarations.comments:
Update an element when it was found by the predicate or append a new element to the end of the array.

```purescript
updateOrSnoc (_ == 2) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,11,3]
updateOrSnoc (_ == 4) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,2,3,11]
```
declarations.title: updateOrSnoc

declarations.comments:
Update an element when it was found by the predicate or push a new element to the front of the array.

```purescript
updateOrCons (_ == 2) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [1,11,3]
updateOrCons (_ == 4) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [11,1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: updateOrCons

declarations.comments:
Finds a single element and returns it together with elements before and after.

```purescript
partitionSides (_ == 3) [1,2,3,4,5] == Just {before: [1,2], found: 3, after: [4,5]}
```
declarations.title: splitOn

declarations.comments:
Find an element and place an element before it.
Could also be thought of as placing the element in the place of the found element and moving al later elements.

```purescript
insertBefore (_ == 2) 10 [1,2,3] == Just [1,10,2,3]
```
declarations.title: insertBefore

declarations.comments:
Find an element and place an element after it.

```purescript
insertAfter (_ == 2) 10 [1,2,3] == Just [1,2,10,3]
```
declarations.title: insertAfter

declarations.comments:
Find an element which could be projected into another value.

```purescript
findMaybe (\x -> if x == 2 then Just "Found two" else Nothing) [1,2,3] == Just "Found Two"
findMaybe (\x -> if x == 2 then Just 2 else Nothing) [1,2,3] == find (_ == 2) [1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: findMaybe

declarations.comments:
Re-export of `difference` from `Data.Array`

```purescript
difference [2, 1] [2, 3] = [1]
```
declarations.title: difference

declarations.comments:
Like `difference` but takes a comparison function.
For each element in the second list, one element in the first list will be removed if the predicate matches.

```purescript
differenceBy (\a b -> toLower a == toLower b) ["apple", "dog"] ["KIWI", "DOG"] == ["apple"]
```
declarations.title: differenceBy

modules.name: Data.Array.Extra.First

modules.comments: Functions that insert an element when it can not be found in the array.

declarations.comments:
Append an element to the end of the array when it could not be found by the predicate.

```purescript
snocWith (_ == 2) [1,3] 2 == Just [1,3,2]
```
declarations.title: snocWith

declarations.comments:
Append an element to the end of the array when it could not be found.

```purescript
snocWith' [1,3] 2 == Just [1,3,2]
```
declarations.title: snocWith'

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and when it was not found return an array with the element pushed to the front.

```purescript
consWith 2 [1,3] == Just [2,1,3]
```
declarations.title: consWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element and when it was not found return an array with the element pushed to the front.

```purescript
consWith [1,3] 2 == Just [2,1,3]
```
declarations.title: consWith'

declarations.comments:
Insert the element into a sorted array but only if the element can not be found by the predicate.

```purescript
insertByWith (_ == 2) (\a b -> compare a b) 2 [1,3]  == Just [1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: insertByWith

declarations.comments:
Insert the element into a sorted array but only if the element didn't exist before.

```purescript
insertByWith (\a b -> compare a b) 2 [1,3]  == Just [1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: insertByWith'

declarations.comments:
Insert an array into another array at the given position.
Returns `Nothing` when the index is out of bounds.

```purescript
unsafeInsertArray 2 [21,22] [1,2,3,4,5] == [1,2,21,22,3,4,5]
```
declarations.title: insertArray

modules.name: Data.Array.Extra.Insert

modules.comments: Functions that find the last matching element based on a predicate and then do something with the array.

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return it together with the array without the element.

```purescript
pick (_ == 2) [1,2,3] == Just {yes: 2, no: [1,3]}
```
declarations.title: pick

declarations.comments:
Find an element and return an array without that element when it was found.

```purescript
delete [2,1,3,2] 2 == Just [2,1,3]
```
declarations.title: delete

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array without that element when it was found.

```purescript
deleteWith (_ == 2) [2,1,3,2] == Just [2,1,3]
```
declarations.title: deleteWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array with the updated element when it was found

```purescript
updateWith (_ == 2) 4 [1,2,3] == Just [1,4,3]
```
declarations.title: updateWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array with the element replaced by an array.

```purescript
updateFirstArrayWith (_ == 2) [21,22] [1,2,3,4,5] == Just [1,2,21,22,3,4,5]
```
declarations.title: updateFirstArrayWith

declarations.comments:
Find an element by a predicate and return an array with the updated element when it was found

```purescript
modifyWith (_ == 2) (* 3) [1,2,3] == Just [1,6,3]
```
declarations.title: modifyWith

declarations.comments:
Modify an element when it was found by the predicate or append a new element to the end of the array.

```purescript
modifyOrSnoc (_ == 2) (* 3) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,6,3]
modifyOrSnoc (_ == 4) (* 3) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,2,3,11]
```
declarations.title: modifyOrSnoc

declarations.comments:
Modify an element when it was found by the predicate or push a new element to the front of the array.

```purescript
modifyOrCons (_ == 2) (* 3) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [1,6,3]
modifyOrCons (_ == 4) (* 3) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [11,1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: modifyOrCons

declarations.comments:
Update an element when it was found by the predicate or append a new element to the end of the array.

```purescript
updateOrSnoc (_ == 2) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,11,3]
updateOrSnoc (_ == 4) [1,2,3] 11 == Just [1,2,3,11]
```
declarations.title: updateOrSnoc

declarations.comments:
Update an element when it was found by the predicate or push a new element to the front of the array.

```purescript
updateOrCons (_ == 2) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [1,11,3]
updateOrCons (_ == 4) 11 [1,2,3] == Just [11,1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: updateOrCons

declarations.comments:
Finds a single element and returns it together with elements before and after.

```purescript
partitionSides (_ == 3) [1,2,3,4,5] == Just {before: [1,2], found: 3, after: [4,5]}
```
declarations.title: splitOn

declarations.comments:
Find an element and place an element before it.
Could also be thought of as placing the element in the place of the found element and moving al later elements.

```purescript
insertBefore (_ == 2) 10 [1,2,3] == Just [1,10,2,3]
```
declarations.title: insertBefore

declarations.comments:
Find an element and place an element after it.

```purescript
insertAfter (_ == 2) 10 [1,2,3] == Just [1,2,10,3]
```
declarations.title: insertAfter

declarations.comments:
Find an element which could be projected into another value.

```purescript
findMaybe (\x -> if x == 2 then Just "Found two" else Nothing) [1,2,3] == Just "Found Two"
findMaybe (\x -> if x == 2 then Just 2 else Nothing) [1,2,3] == find (_ == 2) [1,2,3]
```
declarations.title: findMaybe

modules.name: Data.Array.Extra.Last

modules.comments: Unsafe but faster functions due to no out of bounds checking.

declarations.comments:
Delete the element at index `i` in an array

```purescript
unsafePartial $ unsafeDeleteAt 1 ["a", "b", "c"] = ["a", "c"]
```
declarations.title: unsafeDeleteAt

declarations.comments:
Insert the element at index `i` in an array

```purescript
unsafePartial $ unsafeInsertAt 1 "b" ["a", "c"] = ["a", "b", "c"]
```
declarations.title: unsafeInsertAt

declarations.comments:
Insert an array into another array at the given position.

```purescript
unsafeInsertArray 2 [21,22] [1,2,3,4,5] == [1,2,21,22,3,4,5]
```
declarations.title: unsafeInsertArray

declarations.comments:
Overwrite the element at index `i` in an array

```purescript
unsafePartial $ unsafeUpdateAt 1 "e" ["a", "b", "c"] = ["a", "e", "c"]
```
declarations.title: unsafeUpdateAt

declarations.comments:
Overwrite the element at index `i` in an array

```purescript
unsafePartial $ unsafeModifyAt 1 (\a -> a <> "e") ["a", "b", "c"] = ["a", "be", "c"]
```
declarations.title: unsafeModifyAt

declarations.comments:
Get the first element in an array. Passing `Nothing` to `unsafeHead` will throw an error at
runtime.
declarations.title: unsafeHead

modules.name: Data.Array.Extra.Unsafe
